BUT gay sex remained illegal in Scotland and Northern Ireland until 1982 as well as those serving in the armed forces, 𝐰𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐬𝐭 𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐩𝐞𝐨𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐰𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐧'𝐭 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐭𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐢𝐧 𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐥𝐞𝐠𝐢𝐬𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐥 𝟐𝟎𝟏𝟎! 👉 1972: The first Pride march was held in London, where 2000 participants supported and contributed. Today, however, this number rises to up to a million, where various Pride events occur throughout the year and across the UK. 👉 1988: Margaret Thatcher introduced Section 28 of the Local Government Act 1988. This banned the 'promotion' of homosexuality by local authorities and in British schools. 👉 1992: The World Health Organization declassified same-sex attraction as a mental illness. 𝐒𝐡𝐨𝐜𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐰𝐚𝐬 𝐨𝐧𝐥𝐲 𝟑𝟏 𝐲𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐬 𝐚𝐠𝐨. 👉 2000: The ban on gay and bisexual people serving in the armed forces was lifted. 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐰𝐚𝐬 𝐨𝐧𝐥𝐲 𝟐𝟒 𝐲𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐬 𝐚𝐠𝐨!! 👉 2002: Same sex couples were given equal rights when it came to adoption. 👉 2004: The Civil Partnership Act passed and The Gender Recognition Act passed. 👉 2013: The Marriage (Same-sex couples) Act was passed, legalizing same-sex marriages. It's clear that we've come a long way, yet the timeline also highlights that progress is an ongoing effort. 𝐈𝐭'𝐬 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐭𝐞 𝐡𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲 𝐲𝐞𝐭. 𝐖𝐞'𝐫𝐞 𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐟𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐋𝐆𝐁𝐓𝐐+ 𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲. #lgbtqhistorymonth #raiseawareness

“International Day Against Homophobia, Biphobia and Transphobia was created in 2004 to draw attention to the violence and discrimination experienced by lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans and intersex people, all of those with diverse sexual orientations, gender identities or expressions and sex characteristics. May 17 was chosen to commemorate the World Health Organization's decision to declassify homosexuality as a mental disorder, in 1990. It is currently celebrated in more than 130 countries, including 37 where same-sex acts are illegal. This year's theme is "No One Left Behind: Equality, Freedom and Justice for All". The world has just celebrated the 75th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights – a document that is much more than a cornerstone of international law: It is a guide to navigate the deeply divided world, a set of values that everyone can live by and ultimately a force of good. And yet, we know that "All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights" represents a promise not yet fulfilled – for 2SLGBTQ2+ people across the world and for everyone experiencing the suffocating impact on their lives of diverse layers of inequalities. This year's IDAHBT theme is a call for unity: Only through solidarity for each other will we create a world without injustice, where no one is left behind.” ❤️🧡💛💚💙💜🤎🖤🤍🩷🩵 #InternationalDayAgainstHomophobiaAndTransphobia #ForeverProud #ForeverProgressing #2SLGBTQ #Equality #Freedom #Justice #IDAHBT

Key facts: 62 countries have laws that criminalize private, consensual, same-sex sexual activity, mainly for men. Almost half of them are Commonwealth jurisdictions. 12 of them have jurisdictions in which the death penalty is imposed or at least a possibility for private, consensual same-sex sexual activity. At least 6 of these implement the death penalty. 14 countries criminalize the gender identity and expression of transgender people. In many more countries, transgender people are targeted by a range of laws that criminalize same-sex activity and vagrancy, hooliganism, and public order offenses. It is important to note that legality of same-sex sexual acts cannot be read as evidence of a safer living environment for people with diverse sexual orientations or gender identities or expressions. In many of the States where consensual same-sex sexual acts are legal, the social stigmatization of people who are perceived as non-heterosexual or non-cisgender remains alarmingly high. Sources: https://lnkd.in/dPWQZUpt https://lnkd.in/dwdYSBU #LGBTQ+ #DEI #humanrights #sexualrights #safety

No one left behind: equality, freedom and justice for all! Today is the International Day Against Homophobia, Biphobia, and Transphobia (IDAHOBIT). With equality, freedom and justice in mind, we want to bring attention to the recently announced review of Relationships, Sex and Health Education (RSHE) in the UK. Following years of targeted anti-trans sentiment, the proposed RSHE guidance states simply that "gender identity should not be taught". Pushing trans and nonbinary people from the public eye doesn't change the reality that we exist. Children should not be brought up with a narrow and unrealistic understanding of human diversity, leaving them woefully unprepared for a naturally diverse world. Simply not teaching about gender will not prevent kids from being trans and non-binary, but it will teach those kids to live in enforced silence and shame. We are still feeling the repercussions of Section 28. A repeat of that injustice is being threatened again, now. The gov review of the RSHE statutory guidance consultation is open now and closes 11:59pm on 11 July 2024. Please fill it out - let's oppose the utter inadequacy of this proposed guidance, together (link in our bio). Not one child or young person should be left behind. Equality, freedom, and justice for ALL! #Proud2Be #Trans #Nonbinary #Gay #Bi #IDAHOBIT #IDAHOBIT2024 #LGBT #LGBTQ #LGBTQIA

That means your personal beliefs do not get to take away other people's freedoms. If you're sitting in this room right now, and you're somebody who thinks I don't, there are people who do this, who thinks I don't think LGBT, any of the letters should exist. Everybody should be heterosexual. How many agree there are people in this country who believe that yes or no? Okay. That's, Hey, you could choose to believe that. That's very different than saying you all have to believe it because I do. Okay. That's not freedom anymore. How many of these are a huge difference when you start sitting in this room thinking, because of what I've been taught, what I believe, everybody must believe this, if you agree with me, that's dangerous to just say dangerous." 👉 Learn more at https://lnkd.in/gntE7Q4Q #CenterForRespect #MikeDomitrz #Culture #Respect

Every day that the Commonwealth Government fails to introduce its long-promised reforms to the Sex Discrimination Act is another day that an LGBTQ student at a religious school wakes up scared to go to school because they can be legally mistreated because of who they are. And another day that an LGBTQ teacher fears losing their job for reasons that have absolutely nothing to do with whether they can actually perform their job. This situation is unacceptable, as is the fact the road to change continues to drag on. We must continue to keep the pressure up on the Albanese Government until they are finally forced to take action. Part of sustaining that pressure is conveying our message, about the urgent need for reform, to new audiences. In that context, a couple of weeks ago I sat down for an extended interview with ex-ABC journalist Josh Szeps, for his podcast ‘Uncomfortable Conversations’, which has now been published. An edited version of that chat can be listened to via Spotify: https://lnkd.in/gnkh-VF7 And found at Apple: https://lnkd.in/gwnQFdKS Or on YouTube: https://lnkd.in/gJvhTvse I understand the full hour-long conversation is available to his paid subscribers, too. Anyway, it was an interesting conversation, and I think/hope I managed to articulate the case for change convincingly. Let me know your thoughts, either way, in the comments. #auslaw #auspol #lgbtiq #sexdiscriminationact #nswpol #antidiscriminationact #religiousfreedom #humanrights

It was created in 2004 to draw the attention of policymakers, opinion leaders, social movements, the public and the media to the violence and discrimination experienced by LGBTQ+ people internationally. In under a decade, May 17 has established itself the single most important date for communities to mobilize on a worldwide scale. The Day represents an annual landmark to draw the attention of decision makers, the media, the public, opinion leaders and local authorities to the alarming situation faced by lesbian, gay, bisexuals, transgender and intersex people and all those who do not conform to majority sexual and gender norms. May 17 is now celebrated in more than 130 countries, including 37 where same-sex acts are illegal, with 1600 events reported from 1280 organizations in 2014. These mobilization unite millions of people in support of the recognition of human rights for all, irrespective of sexual orientation or gender identity or expression. The International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia is not one centralized campaign; rather it is a moment that everyone can take advantage of to take action. The date of May 17th was specifically chosen to commemorate the World Health Organization’s decision in 1990 to declassify homosexuality as a mental disorder. The International Day against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia has received official recognition from several States, international institutions as the European Parliament, and by countless local authorities. Most United Nations agencies also mark the Day with specific events. #ablgbt #ab #yyc #yeg #alberta #ablgbtchamber #businessAB #supportlocal #albertabusiness #supportlocalalberta

I can’t imagine how distressing it must be to be Trans in this current climate. Just imagine being painted as sexual predators, misguided children and sports cheats by turns. Never mind that these narratives contradict, aren’t supported by evidence and are being being used in the same way propaganda has always been used. Time for some basic empathy and time for a history lesson. Remember when it was your sexuality that made you the ‘bogeyman’ or the colour of your skin. Remember when women weren’t allowed to think for themselves or anyone that didn’t own property. This is why we say we have to learn the lessons of history of be doomed to repeat the same mistakes. Here we go repeating those same mistakes again. This time we are ‘othering’ Trans people. Next time it could be you!
